questions.text: In a circuit with both independent and dependent sources, the Superposition theorem is applied by considering:

choices.text: One independent source at a time, with dependent sources always active.
One source (independent or dependent) at a time.
Only one independent source at a time, with dependent sources deactivated.
The theorem cannot be applied to circuits with dependent sources.

questions.text: In a parallel RLC circuit, the bandwidth is given by:

choices.text: $R / L$
$L / R$

questions.text: The "punch-through" effect in a BJT occurs when:

choices.text: The base-emitter junction breaks down.
The collector-base depletion region expands to touch the base-emitter depletion region.
The thermal runaway destroys the transistor.
The transistor enters the saturation region.

questions.text: The primary difference between a depletion-mode and an enhancement-mode MOSFET is that:

choices.text: Depletion-mode MOSFETs are "normally ON"; enhancement-mode are "normally OFF".
Enhancement-mode MOSFETs are "normally ON"; depletion-mode are "normally OFF".
Depletion-mode MOSFETs do not have a gate.
Enhancement-mode MOSFETs are used only in digital logic.

questions.text: An op-amp's "Input Offset Voltage" is the differential input voltage required to:

choices.text: Drive the output to its maximum swing.
Make the open-loop gain infinite.
Make the output voltage exactly zero.
Maximize the Common Mode Rejection Ratio.

questions.text: A "cascode" amplifier configuration is used primarily to:

choices.text: Increase the output voltage swing.
Increase the input impedance.
Reduce the Miller effect and improve high-frequency performance.
Decrease the output impedance.

questions.text: A "dynamic hazard" in a digital circuit is a condition where:

choices.text: The output changes more than once for a single input change that was supposed to cause a single output change.
The circuit consumes power even when idle.
The output is stuck at a single value.
The circuit enters a race condition.

questions.text: An "antifuse" in a Field-Programmable Gate Array (FPGA) is a type of interconnect that:

choices.text: Is normally a high resistance path that can be permanently changed to a low resistance path.
Is normally a low resistance path that can be permanently broken.
Is reconfigurable like an SRAM cell.
Is used to store the configuration data.

questions.text: A "look-ahead carry" adder is faster than a ripple-carry adder because:

choices.text: It uses fewer logic gates.
It generates the carry-in for each bit position simultaneously, without waiting for the previous bit's carry-out.
It uses synchronous flip-flops.
It operates on a higher clock frequency.

questions.text: A "VLIW" (Very Long Instruction Word) architecture is characterized by:

choices.text: Relying on the hardware to find instruction-level parallelism.
A complex instruction set.
Relying on the compiler to bundle multiple, independent, simple instructions into a single very long instruction word.
A deep instruction pipeline.

questions.text: In C, a "flexible array member" is an array of unspecified size that can only be declared as the:

choices.text: First member of a structure.
Last member of a structure that has at least one other member.
A global variable.
A static local variable.

questions.text: What is "type punning" in C, and why can it be dangerous?

choices.text: It is giving a type a new name using typedef. It is always safe.
It is a technique to access a piece of memory as different types, often violating strict aliasing rules and leading to undefined behavior.
It is the process of converting an integer to a float. It can cause a loss of precision.
It refers to using void* pointers, which is a standard and safe practice.

questions.text: In C++, what does "perfect forwarding" refer to?

choices.text: The ability to pass arguments to a function template and have them forwarded to another function with their original value category (lvalue/rvalue) preserved.
A way to ensure a function always returns the correct type.
A linker optimization.
The process of copying an object without invoking the copy constructor.

questions.text: What is the difference between a "structural hazard" and a "data hazard" in a pipeline?

choices.text: They are the same.
A structural hazard is due to resource conflict; a data hazard is due to an instruction needing a result that is not yet available.
A data hazard is a resource conflict; a structural hazard is a dependency issue.
A structural hazard is caused by branches; a data hazard is caused by memory access.

questions.text: What is the purpose of "Random Early Detection" (RED) in a network router?

choices.text: To provide a mechanism for congestion avoidance by randomly dropping packets before the queue is completely full.
To detect and correct bit errors in packets.
To find the shortest path to a destination.
To filter malicious traffic.

questions.text: A problem is in the complexity class "NP-Hard" if:

choices.text: It can be solved in non-deterministic polynomial time.
It is at least as hard as the hardest problems in NP; any NP problem can be reduced to it.
A solution can be verified in polynomial time.
It is undecidable.

questions.text: A "Fibonacci heap" is a data structure used to implement a priority queue that has a better amortized running time for some operations compared to a:

choices.text: Binary heap
B-Tree
Hash table
Stack

questions.text: A "monitor" as a synchronization construct provides mutual exclusion and what other key capability?

choices.text: Condition variables, allowing threads to wait for specific conditions to become true.
The ability to execute in parallel.
Deadlock detection.
Priority inversion handling.

questions.text: What is "Content-Addressable Memory" (CAM)?

choices.text: A type of memory that is accessed by its physical address.
A special type of memory that is searched by its content rather than its address, often used for high-speed searching applications like routing tables.
A computer memory that is much slower than RAM.
Another name for a CPU cache.

questions.text: The "Liskov Substitution Principle" (LSP) in SOLID design states that if S is a subtype of T, then objects of type T may be:

choices.text: Replaced with objects of type S without altering any of the desirable properties of the program.
Converted to type S.
Used to access private members of S.
Inherited from S.

questions.text: In machine learning, "ensemble learning" is a technique that:

choices.text: Uses a single, complex model for prediction.
Combines the predictions of multiple individual models to produce a more accurate result.
Is used only for unsupervised learning.
Focuses on feature selection.

questions.text: In project management, "fast tracking" is a schedule compression technique that involves:

choices.text: Adding more resources to the project.
Reducing the project scope.
Performing activities in parallel that would normally be done in sequence.
Using a more experienced team.

questions.text: An engineer is asked by their manager to approve a design that they know is marginally safe. The ethical course of action is to:

choices.text: Approve the design to keep their job.
Refuse to approve the design and report their concerns about public safety to the appropriate authorities.
Ask a junior engineer to approve it.
Approve the design but write a secret memo about their concerns.

questions.text: A "lookaside buffer" is another name for:

choices.text: A cache
A Translation Lookaside Buffer (TLB)
A register file
A write buffer

questions.text: What is the primary motivation for using a "Gray code" sequence in a mechanical shaft encoder?

choices.text: It requires fewer bits to represent a position.
It is a weighted code, making calculations easier.
It eliminates ambiguity during transitions because only one bit changes at a time.
It is more resistant to magnetic interference.

questions.text: What is the difference between a union and a struct in C in terms of memory alignment?

choices.text: struct members are not aligned; union members are.
The alignment of a union is the alignment of its largest member, while a struct may have padding between members.
They have the same alignment rules.
A union's alignment is always 1 byte.

questions.text: What is "Curiously Recurring Template Pattern" (CRTP) in C++?

choices.text: A common syntax error in templates.
A design pattern where a class X derives from a template class instantiated with X itself.
A way to create recursive functions using templates.
An anti-pattern that should be avoided.

questions.text: In TCP, what is the "silly window syndrome"?

choices.text: A problem where the congestion window grows too large.
A problem caused by sending a large amount of data in very small segments, leading to inefficient use of the network.
A security vulnerability in the windowing mechanism.
The result of a timeout.

questions.text: Cook's theorem proved that the "Boolean Satisfiability Problem" (SAT) is:

choices.text: In P
NP-complete
Undecidable
A context-free language

questions.text: What is a "B+ Tree", and how does it differ from a B-Tree?

choices.text: It is a less efficient version of a B-Tree.
All data pointers are stored only in the leaf nodes, making the leaf nodes a linked list for efficient range queries.
It is a binary version of a B-Tree.
There is no difference.

questions.text: In OS memory management, what is the "buddy system"?

choices.text: A memory allocation algorithm that divides memory into partitions of power-of-2 sizes and tries to find a "buddy" block to merge with upon deallocation.
A page replacement algorithm.
A way for two processes to share memory.
A technique for deadlock prevention.

questions.text: What is "metaprogramming" in software engineering?

choices.text: A style of programming that avoids using functions.
The practice of writing programs that write or manipulate other programs (or themselves).
A type of object-oriented design.
A methodology for project management.

questions.text: What is the primary difference between a "knowledge-based system" and a conventional program?

choices.text: A knowledge-based system has its knowledge base and inference engine separated, making it easier to modify the knowledge.
A conventional program is written in a higher-level language.
There is no difference.
A knowledge-based system cannot use procedural logic.

questions.text: In machine learning, what is a "Support Vector Machine" (SVM)?

choices.text: A supervised learning model that finds a hyperplane that best separates data into classes.
A type of neural network.
A clustering algorithm.
A reinforcement learning algorithm.

questions.text: The "Cost Performance Index" (CPI) in project management is calculated as:

choices.text: $EV / AC$ (Earned Value / Actual Cost)
$EV / PV$ (Earned Value / Planned Value)
$AC / EV$
$PV / EV$

questions.text: An engineer's responsibility of "due diligence" means:

choices.text: Taking reasonable care and effort to ensure that their work meets professional standards and does not cause harm.
Completing a project on the due date.
Paying their professional fees on time.
Attending all project meetings.

questions.text: In a BJT, the "alpha" ($\alpha$) is the ratio of:

choices.text: Collector current to base current ($I_c / I_b$)
Collector current to emitter current ($I_c / I_e$)
Base current to emitter current ($I_b / I_e$)
Emitter current to collector current ($I_e / I_c$)

questions.text: A "Mealy machine" can have fewer states than an equivalent "Moore machine" because:

choices.text: The output is associated with the transitions, allowing for different outputs on the same state.
It is a more powerful type of automaton.
It uses a different type of memory.
It is not restricted to a binary alphabet.

questions.text: In C++, what does the \texttt{explicit} keyword do when applied to a constructor?

choices.text: It makes the constructor private.
It prevents the compiler from using the constructor for implicit type conversions.
It marks the constructor as the default constructor.
It ensures the constructor is inlined.

questions.text: A "control hazard" caused by a conditional branch is often mitigated in modern pipelines using:

choices.text: Data forwarding
Scoreboarding
Speculative execution
Increasing the number of pipeline stages

questions.text: What is "Address Space Layout Randomization" (ASLR)?

choices.text: A memory management technique in operating systems.
A computer security technique that involves randomly arranging the address space positions of key data areas.
A way to optimize database queries.
A network routing protocol.

questions.text: A "lambda calculus" is a formal system in mathematical logic for expressing:

choices.text: Computation based on function abstraction and application.
Set theory.
Graph theory.
Propositional logic.

questions.text: In concurrency, a "futex" (fast userspace mutex) is a:

choices.text: A kernel-level synchronization primitive.
A low-level primitive that allows a thread to wait for a value at a given address to change, avoiding system calls when there is no contention.
A hardware-based lock.
A type of semaphore.

questions.text: The "Decorator" design pattern is used to:

choices.text: Add new responsibilities to an object dynamically without altering its class.
Create objects.
Define a communication channel between objects.
Ensure a class has only one instance.

questions.text: What is a "Generative Adversarial Network" (GAN)?

choices.text: A type of supervised learning model.
A class of machine learning frameworks where two neural networks (a generator and a discriminator) contest with each other.
A reinforcement learning algorithm.
A data clustering method.

questions.text: The "Schedule Performance Index" (SPI) is calculated as $EV / PV$. An SPI of 0.8 indicates the project is:

choices.text: On schedule
Ahead of schedule
Behind schedule
Under budget

questions.text: What is the difference between an "abstract class" and an "interface"?

choices.text: An interface can have method implementations, but an abstract class cannot.
A class can implement multiple interfaces but can only inherit from one abstract class (in many languages).
An abstract class cannot have constructors.
There is no significant difference.

questions.text: In networking, "jitter" is the variation in the:

choices.text: Bandwidth of a connection.
Latency (ping time) of packets over time.
Signal strength.
Packet size.

questions.text: Homomorphic encryption is a form of encryption that allows:

choices.text: Computation to be performed on ciphertext, generating an encrypted result which, when decrypted, matches the result of operations performed on the plaintext.
Encryption using two different keys.
Very fast decryption.
Encryption that cannot be broken.

questions.text: What is a "Byzantine Fault" in a distributed system?

choices.text: A simple crash fault.
A condition where a component can exhibit arbitrary and malicious behavior, including sending conflicting information to different parts of the system.
A network partition.
A temporary loss of service.

questions.text: The "Early effect" in a BJT causes an increase in which h-parameter?
What is the primary advantage of a "Carry-Select Adder"?

choices.text: It has the lowest gate count.
It reduces the propagation delay by pre-calculating the sum for both possible carry-in values (0 and 1).
It is a type of sequential circuit.
It can also perform subtraction.

questions.text: What does the C++ keyword \texttt{mutable} do?

choices.text: It allows a non-const member function to modify a data member, even if the object is const.
It allows a data member of a const object to be modified.
It makes a variable's value unchangeable.
It is a synonym for \texttt{volatile}.

questions.text: In the context of the OSI model, what is a "Protocol Data Unit" (PDU)?

choices.text: A specific protocol like TCP or UDP.
The single unit of information transmitted among peer entities of a computer network.
The physical medium.
A network device.

questions.text: The "halting problem" is an example of a problem that is:

choices.text: Decidable and in P.
Recognizable but not decidable.
In NP but not NP-complete.
Context-free.

questions.text: What is the difference between "cohesion" and "coupling" in software design?

choices.text: High cohesion and high coupling are desirable.
Low cohesion and low coupling are desirable.
High cohesion (relatedness within a module) and low coupling (independence between modules) are desirable.
Low cohesion and high coupling are desirable.

questions.text: What is "transfer learning" in machine learning?

choices.text: A technique where a model trained on one task is re-purposed on a second, related task.
The process of transferring data over a network.
A type of reinforcement learning.
The process of learning from unlabeled data.

questions.text: The "critical path" of a project is the sequence of activities that:

choices.text: Has the largest amount of slack.
Represents the longest path through the project, which determines the shortest possible project duration.
Contains the most expensive activities.
Is performed by the most critical team members.

questions.text: An engineer's ethical duty to "act as a faithful agent" for their client means they must:

choices.text: Always agree with the client, even if the client is wrong.
Protect the client's interests and confidentiality, and avoid conflicts of interest.
Work for free if the client requests it.
Share the client's proprietary information with competitors.

questions.text: What is "Tomásulo's algorithm"?

choices.text: A hardware algorithm for dynamic instruction scheduling that allows for out-of-order execution.
A page replacement algorithm.
A deadlock detection algorithm.
A graph traversal algorithm.

questions.text: A common-emitter amplifier has a load resistance of $10 \, \mathrm{k}\Omega$ and a collector resistance of $10 \, \mathrm{k}\Omega$. If the $\beta$ ($h_{fe}$) of the transistor is 100 and the internal emitter resistance ($r_e$) is $25 \, \Omega$, what is the approximate voltage gain? ($A_v \approx -R_{c_{total}} / r_e$)

A state machine is defined by the following transitions: State A on input 0 goes to B, on 1 goes to A. State B on input 0 goes to A, on 1 goes to B. If the machine starts in state A, which of the following input strings will end in state B?

choices.text: Undefined behavior

questions.text: A system has a 16-bit virtual address and a $4 \, \mathrm{KB}$ page size. How many entries are there in a two-level page table if the first-level page table fits exactly into a single page?

choices.text: The outer table has 16 entries; each inner table has 256 entries.
The outer table has 64 entries; each inner table has 64 entries.
The outer table has 256 entries; each inner table has 16 entries.
The outer table has 4 entries; each inner table has 1024 entries.

questions.text: In the OSI model, what is the PDU (Protocol Data Unit) at the first three layers (from the bottom up)?

choices.text: Bit, Frame, Packet
Packet, Segment, Data
Frame, Packet, Segment
Data, Segment, Packet

questions.text: A 3D point $(1, 2, 3)$ is rotated by 90 degrees around the Z-axis. What are the new coordinates? (Rotation matrix: $\begin{bmatrix} \cos\theta & -\sin\theta & 0 \\ \sin\theta & \cos\theta & 0 \\ 0 & 0 & 1 \end{bmatrix}$)
A system is using the Banker's algorithm. If a request by a process leads to a state where the Need matrix is greater than the Available vector for all processes, the state is:

choices.text: Safe
Guaranteed to be unsafe
Not necessarily unsafe, a safe sequence might still be found
Deadlocked

questions.text: A project has a Planned Value (PV) of \$500, a Cost Performance Index (CPI) of 1.25, and a Schedule Performance Index (SPI) of 0.8. What is the Actual Cost (AC)?

In Diffie-Hellman key exchange, Alice and Bob publicly share a prime $p=23$ and a primitive root $g=5$. Alice chooses a private key $a=4$, and Bob chooses $b=3$. What is the shared secret key they compute?

choices.text: Selects all employees who earn more than the overall average salary.
Selects all employees who earn more than the average salary of their own department.
Selects the average salary for each department.
The query is invalid.

questions.text: The "dependency inversion principle" states that high-level modules should not depend on low-level modules. Both should depend on:

choices.text: Concretions
Abstractions
The main function
Global variables

questions.text: What language does the following CFG generate: $S \to aSb \mid c$?

choices.text: $\{ a^n c b^n \mid n \geq 0 \}$
$\{ a^n b^n c \mid n \geq 0 \}$
$\{ (ab)^n c \mid n \geq 0 \}$

questions.text: In TCP, if the MSS is $1 \, \mathrm{KB}$ and the receiver advertises a window of $64 \, \mathrm{KB}$, and the congestion window is $32 \, \mathrm{KB}$, what is the maximum amount of unacknowledged data the sender can have in transit?

choices.text: $1 \, \mathrm{KB}$
$32 \, \mathrm{KB}$
$64 \, \mathrm{KB}$
$96 \, \mathrm{KB}$

questions.text: A problem is known to be NP-Hard. A new problem is developed, and it is proven that the known NP-Hard problem can be reduced to this new problem in polynomial time. What can be concluded about the new problem?

choices.text: The new problem is in P.
The new problem is also NP-Hard.
The new problem is NP-complete.
Nothing can be concluded.

questions.text: A machine learning model for detecting a rare disease has an accuracy of 99\%. Why might this metric be misleading?

choices.text: A model that always predicts "no disease" could achieve 99\% accuracy if the disease only affects 1\% of the population.
Accuracy is not a valid metric for classification.
99\% accuracy is too low to be useful.
The model is likely overfitting.

questions.text: In a file system using indexed allocation, if the inode has 12 direct pointers, one single indirect pointer, and the block size is $4 \, \mathrm{KB}$, what is the maximum file size? (Assume block pointers are 4 bytes).

choices.text: $48 \, \mathrm{KB}$
$1072 \, \mathrm{KB}$
$4144 \, \mathrm{KB}$
$4 \, \mathrm{GB}$

questions.text: Which design pattern would be most suitable for defining a skeleton of an algorithm in a base class, but letting subclasses override specific steps of the algorithm without changing its structure?

choices.text: Strategy Pattern
Template Method Pattern
Observer Pattern
State Pattern
The code will not compile because a const object is calling a member function.
The code will not compile because the constructor is not const.
The code has undefined behavior.

questions.text: A circuit is described by the Boolean expression $F = (A'B + C)'$. Using De Morgan's laws, what is the equivalent expression?

choices.text: $AB'C'$

questions.text: A project's critical path has an expected duration of 60 days. The path with the second-longest duration is 58 days. What is the total float (slack) of an activity on the critical path?

choices.text: 0 days
2 days
58 days
60 days
